title: 2 Samuel Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who did David ask about to show kindness for Jonathan's sake?
options: Anyone left of the house of Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Anyone left of the house of Saul
questions.explanation: David asked if there was anyone left of the house of Saul to show kindness for Jonathan's sake, as stated in 2 Samuel 9:1.

questions.question: What was the name of the servant from the house of Saul who was called to David?
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba
questions.explanation: Ziba was the servant from the house of Saul who was called to David, according to 2 Samuel 9:2.

questions.question: Who did Ziba say was still alive from the house of Saul?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan's son who is lame
questions.explanation: Ziba told David that Jonathan had a son who was lame on his feet, as noted in 2 Samuel 9:3.

questions.question: Where was Jonathan's son living according to Ziba?
options: In the house of Machir in Lodebar
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of Machir in Lodebar
questions.explanation: Ziba said Jonathan's son was living in the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lodebar (2 Samuel 9:4).

questions.question: What did Mephibosheth do when he came to David?
options: Fell on his face and did reverence
questions.correctAnswer: Fell on his face and did reverence
questions.explanation: When Mephibosheth came to David, he fell on his face and did reverence, as described in 2 Samuel 9:6.

questions.question: What did David promise to Mephibosheth for Jonathan's sake?
options: To restore all the land of Saul and let him eat at David's table
questions.correctAnswer: To restore all the land of Saul and let him eat at David's table
questions.explanation: David promised to restore Mephibosheth all the land of Saul and that he would eat bread continually at the king's table (2 Samuel 9:7).

questions.question: How did Mephibosheth describe himself to David?
options: As a servant of the king
questions.correctAnswer: As a dead dog
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth bowed and said he was like a 'dead dog,' showing humility (2 Samuel 9:8).

questions.question: Who did David instruct to till the land for Mephibosheth?
options: Ziba and his sons and servants
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba and his sons and servants
questions.explanation: David told Ziba, along with his sons and servants, to till the land for Mephibosheth so he would have food (2 Samuel 9:10).

questions.question: How many sons did Ziba have?
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen
questions.explanation: The text states that Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants (2 Samuel 9:10).

questions.question: What relation was Micha to Mephibosheth?
questions.correctAnswer: His young son
questions.explanation: Micha was Mephibosheth's young son as mentioned in 2 Samuel 9:12.

questions.question: True or False: Mephibosheth ate bread at the king’s table continually.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth ate continually at the king's table according to 2 Samuel 9:13.

questions.question: True or False: Mephibosheth was lame on both his feet.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter mentions Mephibosheth was lame on both his feet (2 Samuel 9:13).

questions.question: True or False: David sent for Mephibosheth from Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David sent for Mephibosheth from the house of Machir in Lodebar, not Jerusalem (2 Samuel 9:5).

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'I will surely shew thee kindness for Jonathan thy father's sake, and will restore thee all the ______ of Saul thy father.'
questions.correctAnswer: land
questions.explanation: David said he would restore all the land of Saul to Mephibosheth (2 Samuel 9:7).

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Now Ziba had ______ sons and twenty servants.'
questions.correctAnswer: fifteen
questions.explanation: The verse states Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants (2 Samuel 9:10).

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to show kindness to someone who has wronged their family. Based on 2 Samuel 9, what biblical truth would you share about kindness and forgiveness?
options: Kindness should be shown for the sake of covenant relationships and love, even to those outside your immediate family
Kindness is only for those who deserve it
Kindness should be withheld to protect your own interests
Kindness is optional depending on the situation
questions.correctAnswer: Kindness should be shown for the sake of covenant relationships and love, even to those outside your immediate family
questions.explanation: David sought to show kindness for Jonathan's sake to Mephibosheth, demonstrating faithfulness and love beyond personal gain (2 Samuel 9:1, 9:7). This teaches us about forgiveness and kindness rooted in covenant loyalty.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 9 teach us about the importance of trust and obedience in serving others?
options: Ziba faithfully obeyed the king’s commands to serve Mephibosheth and work the land
Ziba ignored the king’s commands and acted selfishly
Obedience to leaders is not necessary in serving others
Trust is not important when serving others
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba faithfully obeyed the king’s commands to serve Mephibosheth and work the land
questions.explanation: Ziba responded to David’s instructions with willingness to serve (2 Samuel 9:11). This models obedience and trust in leadership as part of serving others faithfully.

questions.question: Based on 2 Samuel 9, what can we learn about God's provision and care for those who are vulnerable?
options: God provides for the vulnerable through the kindness and stewardship of others
God leaves the vulnerable to fend for themselves
Provision must be earned by personal merit
questions.correctAnswer: God provides for the vulnerable through the kindness and stewardship of others
questions.explanation: David restored Mephibosheth’s land and arranged for his provision at the king's table (2 Samuel 9:7, 9:9-10), showing God’s care through human kindness and stewardship.

questions.question: What does Mephibosheth’s humility in 2 Samuel 9 teach us about Christian character?
options: True humility acknowledges one's unworthiness but trusts in God’s grace
Humility is showing weakness to others
Humility means refusing help from others
questions.correctAnswer: True humility acknowledges one's unworthiness but trusts in God’s grace
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth called himself a 'dead dog' yet accepted David’s kindness (2 Samuel 9:8), demonstrating humility grounded in trust rather than self-condemnation.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment after losing family inheritance. What does 2 Samuel 9 teach about contentment and God’s provision?
options: Contentment comes from trusting God’s provision, as Mephibosheth ate at the king’s table despite his disability
Contentment depends on regaining everything lost
Contentment is unrelated to God’s provision
questions.correctAnswer: Contentment comes from trusting God’s provision, as Mephibosheth ate at the king’s table despite his disability
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth dwelt in Jerusalem and ate at the king’s table continually (2 Samuel 9:13), showing contentment through God’s provision and grace.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 9 encourage believers to demonstrate faithfulness to past commitments and relationships?
options: David showed kindness to Saul’s family for Jonathan’s sake, honoring past covenant promises
Faithfulness is only important in present relationships
Past commitments can be ignored if inconvenient
questions.correctAnswer: David showed kindness to Saul’s family for Jonathan’s sake, honoring past covenant promises
questions.explanation: David’s motivation to help Mephibosheth was his covenant with Jonathan (2 Samuel 9:1, 9:7), teaching us about honoring God-ordained relationships.

questions.question: What does the arrangement of Mephibosheth eating at the king’s table teach about inclusion and honor in Christian fellowship?
options: Believers should include and honor others, regardless of their status or disability
Only the strong should be honored in fellowship
Inclusion is optional based on usefulness
Honor is earned by status alone
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should include and honor others, regardless of their status or disability
questions.explanation: David made Mephibosheth a regular at his table like one of his sons (2 Samuel 9:11), showing inclusion and honor despite Mephibosheth’s physical condition.

questions.question: True or False: The passage in 2 Samuel 9 shows that God’s kindness can be mediated through human actions.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David’s kindness to Mephibosheth is described as showing 'the kindness of God' (2 Samuel 9:3), demonstrating that God’s grace can work through people.

questions.question: How can 2 Samuel 9 guide a believer facing trials that cause physical or emotional limitations?
options: God can still provide honor, provision, and inclusion despite limitations
Limitations mean God’s blessing is withdrawn
Believers with limitations should be excluded from fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: God can still provide honor, provision, and inclusion despite limitations
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth was lame but was honored and cared for by David (2 Samuel 9:6, 9:13), showing God’s grace transcends physical limitations.

questions.question: What lesson about stewardship and work ethic can be drawn from David’s instructions to Ziba in 2 Samuel 9?
options: Work should be done diligently to provide for those under our care
Work ethic is unimportant if you have privilege
Stewardship is only for personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Work should be done diligently to provide for those under our care
questions.explanation: David instructed Ziba and his household to work the land to produce food for Mephibosheth (2 Samuel 9:10), emphasizing diligence and stewardship.

questions.question: True or False: Mephibosheth responded with pride when David showed him kindness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth humbly bowed and referred to himself as a 'dead dog' (2 Samuel 9:8), demonstrating humility rather than pride.

questions.question: A new believer wants to understand how to honor family legacy while trusting God’s grace. What does 2 Samuel 9 teach about this balance?
options: Honor family by showing kindness and trusting God to provide what we cannot earn
Rely solely on family legacy without faith
Earn God’s grace through family status
questions.correctAnswer: Honor family by showing kindness and trusting God to provide what we cannot earn
questions.explanation: David honored Jonathan’s family by kindness and restored what belonged to Saul’s house, while Mephibosheth humbly accepted this grace (2 Samuel 9:7-8).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Mephibosheth was lame on ______ feet.
questions.correctAnswer: both
questions.explanation: The text states Mephibosheth was lame on both his feet (2 Samuel 9:3, 9:13), indicating his physical disability.

questions.question: What does David’s action of calling Ziba and confirming his identity teach about leadership and responsibility?
options: Leaders should verify information and entrust responsibilities carefully
Leaders can act without verifying facts
Responsibility is only for family members
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should verify information and entrust responsibilities carefully
questions.explanation: David asked Ziba directly if he was his servant before proceeding (2 Samuel 9:2), showing prudent leadership and care in responsibilities.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 9 instruct believers about the role of family and children in God’s covenant promises?
options: God’s promises extend to descendants, as Mephibosheth had a son, Micha
Only the firstborn child matters in covenant
Children are excluded from God’s promises
Family has no role in God’s covenant
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promises extend to descendants, as Mephibosheth had a son, Micha
questions.explanation: The chapter notes Mephibosheth’s son Micha (2 Samuel 9:12), showing the ongoing covenantal blessing through family lines.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 9.

questions.question: What motivated King David to seek out any remaining members of Saul's house?
options: To show kindness for Jonathan's sake
To claim Saul's throne for himself
questions.correctAnswer: To show kindness for Jonathan's sake
questions.explanation: David explicitly states his intent to show kindness for Jonathan's sake (2 Samuel 9:1), highlighting the covenantal loyalty between David and Jonathan.

questions.question: Who was the servant of Saul that informed David about Jonathan's son?
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba
questions.explanation: Ziba, identified as Saul’s servant, was the one summoned by David and who informed him about Jonathan's son (2 Samuel 9:2-3).

questions.question: Where was Mephibosheth living before David brought him to Jerusalem?
options: In the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lodebar
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lodebar
questions.explanation: Ziba reported that Mephibosheth was living in the house of Machir in Lodebar, a location outside Jerusalem, which David then sent for him (2 Samuel 9:4-5).

questions.question: How did Mephibosheth respond when he first came before King David?
options: He fell on his face and did reverence
questions.correctAnswer: He fell on his face and did reverence
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth showed humility and respect by falling on his face and reverencing David upon meeting him (2 Samuel 9:6).

questions.question: What specific kindness did David promise to Mephibosheth for Jonathan’s sake?
options: Restoration of Saul’s land and continual provision at David’s table
Granting him the throne of Israel
Sending him into exile with honor
Appointing him as a military commander
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration of Saul’s land and continual provision at David’s table
questions.explanation: David promised to restore Saul's land to Mephibosheth and provide for him continually at his own table (2 Samuel 9:7).

questions.question: What is the significance of Mephibosheth calling himself a 'dead dog' in the cultural context of ancient Israel?
options: Claiming to be a fierce warrior
questions.correctAnswer: Expressing unworthiness and humility
questions.explanation: In ancient Israelite culture, dogs were considered unclean; Mephibosheth’s self-description as a 'dead dog' (2 Samuel 9:8) reflects deep humility and a sense of low status.

questions.question: What role did Ziba and his household have after David restored Saul’s property to Mephibosheth?
options: They were to till the land and bring in the fruits for Mephibosheth
They were to serve as soldiers for David
They were to become priests in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They were to till the land and bring in the fruits for Mephibosheth
questions.explanation: David commanded Ziba, his sons, and servants to farm the land so Mephibosheth could have food, showing a servant-laborer relationship (2 Samuel 9:9-10).

questions.question: How many sons and servants did Ziba have to work the land for Mephibosheth?
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen sons and twenty servants
questions.explanation: The text specifies that Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants who were to cultivate the land for Mephibosheth (2 Samuel 9:10).

questions.question: How did David treat Mephibosheth in relation to his own family at the royal table?
options: He allowed him to eat as one of the king's sons
He sent him away from the palace
questions.correctAnswer: He allowed him to eat as one of the king's sons
questions.explanation: David treated Mephibosheth as a son by having him eat continually at the king’s table, symbolizing acceptance and honor (2 Samuel 9:11).

questions.question: What was the name of Mephibosheth’s young son mentioned in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Micha
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth’s young son was named Micha, as recorded in 2 Samuel 9:12.

questions.question: True or False: Mephibosheth was lame on both feet according to this chapter.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter explicitly states Mephibosheth was lame on both his feet (2 Samuel 9:13).

questions.question: How does David’s kindness to Mephibosheth foreshadow New Testament themes of grace and covenant faithfulness?
options: It reflects God’s unmerited favor extended to the undeserving
It emphasizes strict justice without mercy
It demonstrates human effort to earn salvation
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God’s unmerited favor extended to the undeserving
questions.explanation: David’s gracious restoration to Mephibosheth, despite his disability and royal lineage, parallels the biblical theme of grace where favor is given unearned, a concept central to the New Testament (2 Samuel 9:7).

questions.question: What literary device is primarily demonstrated by the movement from Mephibosheth’s low status to his honored place at the king’s table?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiastic structure emphasizing reversal
questions.explanation: The narrative’s structure shows a reversal of fortunes, a chiastic literary device common in Hebrew scripture, highlighting Mephibosheth’s movement from lowly status to honor (2 Samuel 9:6–11).

questions.question: In the historical Near Eastern context, what does David’s act of restoring Saul’s land to Mephibosheth symbolize?
options: A reaffirmation of covenant loyalty and political legitimacy
An act of rebellion against Saul’s lineage
A customary punishment for royal heirs
questions.correctAnswer: A reaffirmation of covenant loyalty and political legitimacy
questions.explanation: Restoring Saul’s land signifies David’s loyalty to the covenant with Jonathan and reinforces his political legitimacy by honoring the previous king’s family (2 Samuel 9:7-9).

questions.question: Which Old Testament covenant theme is most directly illustrated by David’s kindness to Jonathan’s son?
options: The Mosaic law of sacrificial offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to covenant promises
questions.explanation: David’s actions demonstrate faithfulness to his covenant with Jonathan, fulfilling the biblical theme of loyalty and promise-keeping (2 Samuel 9:1, 7).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What motivated King David to seek out someone from the house of Saul to show kindness?
questions.correctAnswer: For Jonathan's sake
questions.explanation: David's motivation is explicitly stated in 2 Samuel 9:1, showing his loyalty and covenant faithfulness to Jonathan, reflecting God's covenant love (Luke 1:72-73; Romans 11:29; Psalm 89:28; 1 Samuel 20:14-15).

questions.question: Who was the servant from Saul's house that David first summoned?
questions.correctAnswer: Ziba
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:2 identifies Ziba as the servant called by David, demonstrating the role of servants in God's providential plan (Genesis 24:2-4; Exodus 21:5; Ruth 2:2; 1 Kings 1:2).

questions.question: What condition did Jonathan's son, Mephibosheth, have?
options: He was lame on his feet
questions.correctAnswer: He was lame on his feet
questions.explanation: The text in 2 Samuel 9:3 states Mephibosheth was lame, emphasizing human frailty and God's grace in restoration (John 5:5-9; 2 Corinthians 12:7-10; Psalm 73:26; Isaiah 35:6).

questions.question: Where was Mephibosheth living before David brought him to Jerusalem?
options: In the house of Machir in Lodebar
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of Machir in Lodebar
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:4 shows Mephibosheth's residence, revealing God's providence in unexpected places (Genesis 37:28; Ruth 1:1; Jeremiah 29:4-7; Acts 17:26).

questions.question: What was David’s promise to Mephibosheth regarding his inheritance?
options: All the land of Saul would be restored to him
He would be made a priest
questions.correctAnswer: All the land of Saul would be restored to him
questions.explanation: David promises restoration of Saul's lands in 2 Samuel 9:7, illustrating God's restorative justice and covenant faithfulness (Psalm 37:11; Isaiah 61:4; Luke 1:54; Acts 3:21).

questions.question: How did Mephibosheth respond to David's kindness?
options: He called himself a dead dog
questions.correctAnswer: He called himself a dead dog
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth’s humility is shown in 2 Samuel 9:8, reflecting human unworthiness before God’s grace (Luke 18:13; Isaiah 64:6; Romans 7:18; Psalm 22:6).

questions.question: What role did Ziba and his household have in relation to Mephibosheth's inheritance?
options: They were to till the land and bring in its fruits for Mephibosheth
They were to serve David directly
They were to leave the land
questions.correctAnswer: They were to till the land and bring in its fruits for Mephibosheth
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:10 states Ziba’s family was to work the land for Mephibosheth, demonstrating stewardship and provision through community (Genesis 4:2; Nehemiah 5:5; Acts 2:44-45; 1 Timothy 5:8).

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 9, how often did Mephibosheth eat at the king’s table?
questions.correctAnswer: Continually
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:7 and 13 stress Mephibosheth’s continual place at the king’s table, symbolizing acceptance and inclusion in God’s covenant family (Luke 22:30; Revelation 3:20; Psalm 23:5; John 6:35).

questions.question: What is the significance of Mephibosheth eating at the king’s table 'as one of the king’s sons'?
options: It signifies full acceptance and honor
It means he was adopted officially
It was a symbolic gesture with no real effect
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies full acceptance and honor
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:11 shows Mephibosheth’s honored status, illustrating themes of adoption and reconciliation in God’s kingdom (Romans 8:15; Galatians 4:5; Ephesians 1:5; John 1:12).

questions.question: Who was the father of the young son Micha, mentioned in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Mephibosheth
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:12 identifies Mephibosheth as Micha’s father, highlighting the continuation of God’s covenant promises through generations (Genesis 17:7; 2 Samuel 7:12; Hebrews 11:12; Psalm 89:3-4).

questions.question: What does Mephibosheth’s physical lameness symbolize theologically in the biblical narrative?
options: Human brokenness and the need for divine grace
questions.correctAnswer: Human brokenness and the need for divine grace
questions.explanation: His lameness (2 Samuel 9:3, 13) represents human weakness redeemed by God's kindness, aligning with biblical themes of healing and restoration (Isaiah 35:6; John 5:8-9; 2 Corinthians 12:9; Psalm 71:20).

questions.question: What does David’s kindness to Mephibosheth illustrate about God's character?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant faithfulness and mercy
questions.explanation: David’s actions (2 Samuel 9:7) exemplify God’s merciful covenant loyalty, consistent with Scripture (Exodus 34:6; Lamentations 3:22; Psalm 103:8; Ephesians 2:4-5).

questions.question: How does this chapter contribute to the biblical theme of covenant loyalty?
options: By showing David’s commitment to Jonathan’s family
By establishing a new covenant with Saul
questions.correctAnswer: By showing David’s commitment to Jonathan’s family
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:1-7 highlights David’s loyalty to Jonathan’s family, reflecting God’s unbreakable covenantal love (Genesis 9:16; Psalm 89:34; Jeremiah 31:3; Hebrews 10:23).

questions.question: What theological truth can be drawn from Mephibosheth’s reception despite his disability and low status?
options: God’s grace extends to the weak and lowly
Only the strong are chosen by God
God favors the wealthy and powerful
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace extends to the weak and lowly
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth’s inclusion (2 Samuel 9:8, 13) demonstrates God’s grace to the marginalized, consistent with biblical teaching (1 Corinthians 1:27-29; Luke 4:18; James 2:5; Isaiah 66:2).

questions.question: What does the provision for Mephibosheth by Ziba and his household illustrate about community and responsibility?
options: The role of others in supporting those in need
Isolation is preferred for the disabled
Every person must fend for themselves
Only kings are responsible for provision
questions.correctAnswer: The role of others in supporting those in need
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 9:10-11 shows communal responsibility, aligning with biblical principles of mutual care (Acts 2:44-45; Galatians 6:2; Leviticus 25:35; 1 John 3:17).

questions.question: How does the story of Mephibosheth foreshadow Christ’s redemptive work?
options: A broken one restored and honored at the king’s table
questions.correctAnswer: A broken one restored and honored at the king’s table
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth’s restoration symbolizes Christ’s redemption of sinners, making them heirs of God’s kingdom (Luke 15:24; Romans 5:6-8; Ephesians 2:8-10; Hebrews 12:2).
